title: Five ways Android is much better than iOS
text:
Here are five cool Android features that make me want to abandon my iPhone.

Must read: The 2019 iPhone 11 will be annoying, boring, and expensive

#1: Screen Pinning

A quick and simple way to lock your Android smartphone in a single app to prevent accessing other apps – handy when handing your smartphone to someone else.

This feature needs to be turned on – and how to do that will vary, but Screen Pinning on stock Android 9 can be found in Security – and once that's been done press the square navigation button to enter the Recent Apps view and tap on an app's icon to pin the window.

#2: Split screen

I love this feature.

It's likely my favorite Android feature. Press the square navigation button to enter the Recent Apps view and tap on the two bars above an app to activate. Note that not all apps support this feature.

#3: Developer Options

Get access to a whole bunch of cool Android features. Developer options can be enabled by navigating to About phone section of your Settings app and finding the Build number. Tap on this repeatedly until you are asked to enter your passcode to enable the feature.

Developer options unlocks a vast array of features, from in-depth networking options to getting your hands on debugging information.

#4: Fast-app switching

Quickly switch back to the last app you were using by double-tapping the square navigation key. This is a super-fast way to repeatedly toggle between a pair of apps.

#5: Android Flags

Now that you know how to access Developer options, here's something you can do while you are there – turn on Android Flags.

What are Android Flags? Well, if you know what Google Chrome Flags are, you're already ahead of the gamer. Android Flags allow you to try out new features that have not yet made it into the final release.

Bonus: Google Maps

Another great Android feature is where Google Maps minimizes into a smaller window that floats on top of other apps when you are using it to navigate but shift to using a different app.

What are your favorite Android – or iOS – features? Let me know below!
